#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=2. An Affordable Playground
#Text=2.1. An SDN-Enabled Multi-Site Clouds Playground

#Text=A Playground is defined as a miniaturized and customizable testbed that is easy to build and operate for various research experiments by a tiny-size DevOps-style team of developers and operators .

#Text=Mainly , we focus on establishing a multi-site playground infrastructure where playground resources are physically distributed across multiple geographical sites but logically inter-connected with each other to offer a unified shared pool of resources .

#Text=A tiny-size team of people ( i.e. , operators ) should provision and control the multi-site isolated resources , which is openly accessible by a group of people ( i.e. , developers ) from all involved sites .
#Text=As depicted in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=, the proposed multi-site playground has several vital entities , which are discussed below :
#Text=Playground Sites with Hyper-converged Boxes .
#Text=When playground developers want to perform their experiments , they can dynamically acquire dedicated resources from the pool of multi-site resources .

#Text=For the customizable ( i.e. , software-defined ) playground , the resource infrastructure of the multi-site playground should be composable ( e.g. , programmable ) in terms of computing , storage , and networking types of resources .

#Text=By leveraging the growing popularity toward hyper-converged appliances that integrate computing , storage , and networking resources into a single box-style entity , we can enable the multi-site resource pool that ready to be customized and scaled-out without the manual intervention of playground operators .

#Text=Thus , in our approach , each playground site is equipped with a box-style of hyper-converged resources , denoted as SmartX Box , the hyper-converged box-style resource that should be useful in supporting the required composability by comfortably accommodating virtualized and programmable resources .
#Text=Multiple types of SmartX Box should be designed and deployed for different purposes , such as SD-WAN , SDN-enabled clouds , and access extension support .
#Text=However , the critical aspects of those boxes design are similar : open , agile , and economic resources .
#Text=Furthermore , the SmartX Box can be divided into three main abstractions , which are box , function , and inter-connect .
#Text=The box represents all the server-based hardware that runs Linux as a baseline open-source operating system for other software-based functions .
#Text=The function represents virtual functions ( e.g. , virtual machine , virtual switch , or virtual router ) , which are implemented by using a set of open-source software .

#Text=Finally , the inter-connect is representing the path/link between functions or boxes which include the tunnel-based overlay networking because playground sites are spread over the heterogeneous underlay network infrastructure .
#Text=Playground Tower with Centers .

#Text=To satisfy the dynamic requirements of playground developers on diversified functionalities over distributed but miniaturized resource pools , the proposed playground should integrate the emerging technology paradigms such as the SDN , cloud computing , and Internet of Things ( IoT ) .

#Text=However , the SDN-enabled multi-site clouds combination brings new complexities for the playground operators , since multi-site clouds resources , connected via SDN-based networks , demand various software-based DevOps- automation tools to build , operate , and use automatically .

#Text=Thus , we propose the concept of Playground Tower , which provides a logical space-like abstraction in a centralized location , which leads the operation of the multi-site playground by following the concept of “ monitor and control ” tower .

#Text=From the tower , the DevOps team can enjoy a panoramic view of playground resources that are distributed over underlay networks , and quickly manage and use those resources for their experiments .
#Text=The playground tower systematically covers various functional requirements of operating a multi-site playground by employing several centers , also depicted in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=.
#Text=First , Provisioning Center ( P-center ) is responsible for remote installation and configuration of multi-site playground resources .
#Text=Visibility Center ( V-center ) covers playground visibility and provides panoramic visualization support .
#Text=Orchestration Center ( O-center ) handles the management level issues with the assistance of controllers ( e.g. , SDN/cloud controllers ) .
#Text=Thus , several software-based tools are used and developed by leveraging open-source software .
#Text=For example , to provision SmartX Box , P-Center provides an automation framework such as Chef and MaaS .

#Text=To continuously operate by re-configuring the playground resources , O-Center provides a set of interfaces ( e.g. , CLI , API , Web UI ) to meet the varying requirements of playground developers .
#Text=Finally , to monitor the playground resources and traffic flows , V-Center provides playground visibility data in an accessible format for visualization and analysis .
#Text=2.2. Affordable Playground with SmartX Box

#Text=As mentioned earlier , to specifically address the affordability of multi-site playground , the resources should be open without any configuration/monitoring limitations , agile to adopt new technologies or match experiment requirements , and economics by the deployment of low-cost commodity hardware .

#Text=Open-source software in converged SDI with SDN , cloud , and Network Function Virtualization ( NFV ) integration , and the support of open-source hardware are the main drivers of the development of hyper-converged box-style resources .
